column3: from the Greek agiero, meaning to assemble). [SEP] From the sixth century [SEP] b.c. [SEP] , this area played host to a number of activities including religious and political meetings, law courts, education, shopping, or simply passing the time of day. [SEP] Here Socrates regaled the people with his philosophical theories — unfortunately for him he fell foul of the authorities and was put to death in 403 [SEP] b.c. [SEP] St. Paul met an audience of “skeptics” who argued against him when he gave a speech here in [SEP] a.d. [SEP] 51. [SEP] The whole area was razed during Barbarian attacks in the centuries following the fall of the Roman Empire and was covered with new buildings during Byzantine times, all of which had to be cleared when excavations began. column1: Hydra Only 1 hour 15 minutes from Athens by hydrofoil, Hydra is the most exclusive of the Saronic islands, and your approach into the harbor is the most dramatic. [SEP] The beautiful port of Hydra Town keeps its secret hidden until the very last moment and when the panorama
column3: into view it’s time to get the camera ready. [SEP] Above the shoreline of the narrow cove lie a series of low hills, and each of these are blanketed with Neo-Classical Italianate mansions painted in myriad dusty hues. [SEP] There are no cars on Hydra — only donkeys. [SEP] No sandy beaches make the water some of the clearest in the area for snorkeling. [SEP] Still, most people don’t visit Hydra for any activity other than to “see and be seen.” [SEP] In the 1960s the island was an artist colony and today it has developed into a place for the beautiful people. [SEP] The boutiques are some of the most exclusive in the Mediterranean, intermingled with the Bohemian craft galleries, exclusive restaurants, tavernas, chic cafés, and Greek ouzeries.

[SEP] The Bahamian people are among the friendliest you’ll ever meet, and they are eager to share the homeland they love with visitors. [SEP] The population is a fascinating mixture of descendants of the Loyalist settlers who left America after the American Revolution, freedom lovers who escaped religious persecution, and ex-slaves set free following emancipation. [SEP] This mixture, which could have produced a society fraught with problems, has evolved into a gentle, sociable, and happy people, proud of their homeland and the progress they have made since independence in 1973. [SEP] With a stable economy, good health, and no taxes, it’s no wonder that a smile
column3: naturally to all Bahamians. [SEP] All the communities still have strong religious faith, the pretty churches are full on Sundays, and a conversation about some future event always ends with “…God willing” or “…with the Lord’s blessing.” [SEP] To make the most of your trip you’ll need to tune your mind to “Bahamian time.” [SEP] On New Providence and Grand Bahama this may not be much slower than at home, but on the Out Islands, time definitely runs more slowly, and nothing is so important that it can’t wait a while. [SEP] People are more important than to-do lists, so a leisurely exchange of greetings and an inquiry about your family’s well-being precedes any business activity. [SEP] This genuine thoughtfulness also extends to visitors; someone will always go out of their way to be helpful, i

[SEP] The Exumas are divided into three distinct sections: Great Exuma Island, Little Exuma Island, and the Exhuma Cays, which lie north of the main islands. [SEP] The capital, George Town, on Great Exuma Island, is served by regular flights from Nassau and makes the most convenient base for non-sailors. [SEP] It has a sleepy and laid-back atmosphere and offers a couple of hotels and restaurants. [SEP] A compact straw and vegetable market sits at the main crossroads. [SEP] The town lies on the coast at Elizabeth Harbour, a large, sheltered stretch of water that is a popular stopping off point for sailors. [SEP] The quiet town
column3: to life every April when it hosts the Family Island Regatta. [SEP] Thousands of Bahamian working boats fill Elizabeth Harbour, their crews vying for the right to call themselves champion of the regatta. [SEP] From George Town you can take the short ferry trip to nearby Stocking Cay. [SEP] The ten-minute journey across the sound (courtesy of the Club Peace and Plenty hotel) takes you to an island of sublime beaches, underwater caves to dive in, and rocky inlets to explore by snorkel. [SEP] You can find sand dollars and starfish and spot rays and turtles. [SEP] The few holiday homes do nothing to spoil the natural beauty, and you’ll still be able to find a deserted beach in one of the many sheltered bays.

column1: Shops take advantage of the tourist traffic to sell the products of other islands, too — embroidery and songket fabrics from Sumatra, primitive art from Irian Jaya, and silver from Sulawesi. [SEP] Lombok: Craft skills in Lombok tend to be devoted to household objects that can have a somewhat austere functional beauty. [SEP] Look for the delicate, tightly-woven basketware, whether in mats, boxes, bowls, and bags, or the common Lombok souvenir of a model rice-barn. [SEP] Painted wood boxes to store spices, tobacco, or jewelry are attractive. [SEP] Simple red pottery
column3: from Penujak, and black pots from Rungkang are bound in an intricately woven basket. [SEP] Necessities: Some supermarkets and convenience stores have opened in Denpasar, such as Tiara Dewata, on Jalan Jenderal Sutoyo, with books, shoes, cosmetics, and even a playground for children and a swimming pool. [SEP] There is a similar big shopping center near the airport, while smaller ones can be found in Kuta, Nusa Dua, Senggigi, and Lombok. [SEP] In big towns, modern grocery shops, with big red “K” signs (Circle K) are open 24 hours a day and sell all kinds of necessities.

column1: A short diversion eastwards will bring you to Blahbatuh, where the palace compound, Puri Blahbatuh, has turned into a commercial orchid nursery, sometimes referred to as Puri Anggrek (Orchid Palace). [SEP] Nearby, Belega specializes in bamboo, producing massive pieces of furniture. [SEP] You’ll see them on display along the main street, and also in some of Bali’s hotels. [SEP] Then
column3: Bona, a center of basketry which also bills itself as the home of the kecak dance. [SEP] The regular performances here are certainly more complete than most versions. [SEP] Back on the road to Ubud: Mas is famous for its woodcarvers, furniture makers, and mask-carvers. [SEP] Vast numbers of shops and workshops line the long main street. [SEP] Unless a shop has been specifically recommended, just stop anywhere and look inside, without buying right away. [SEP] Then investigate the side streets. [SEP] Away from the traffic, you might find an entire family producing wooden hangings for the export market.

column1: A regular passenger and car ferry makes two or three sailings per day to Lombok. [SEP] The voyage can be rough and may take longer than the scheduled four hours. [SEP] Many visitors opt for the newer, faster, and more expensive twin-hull Mabua Express ferry from Benoa Port (see page 75), but backpackers and most locals prefer this traditional, albeit less comfortable, route. [SEP] Fishermen land their catches at Padangbai’s small busy beach, which is jammed with boats, just to the north of the main jetty. [SEP] Facing it at the far end are two or three simple but adequate cottage-style homestays. [SEP] You can arrange diving or fishing trips here, but the water in the bay looks too dirty for swimming. [SEP] Beyond Padangbai
column3: the broad sweep of Amuk Bay, site of a controversial new oil terminal. [SEP] At its eastern end, after the coast road crosses an iron bridge, a track leads down to the sea at the village of Buitan, also called Balina Beach, the name of its main hotel and SCUBA-diving center. [SEP] Candi Dasa (pronounced Chandi Dasa)

column1: Bangli On the main road from the south towards Mount Batur, the chief town of the former rajadom of Bangli looks like a nursery for gorgeous flowering shrubs. [SEP] It
column3: alive every three days for the big morning market in the central square. [SEP] To the south of town on the Gianyar road is Pura Dalem Penuggekan, a typical example of the many temples for the dead: Carved friezes show the nightmarish tortures awaiting sinners in the after-life. [SEP] On the northern outskirts, the chief temple of the former rajadom of Bangli, Pura Kehen, comprises the typical three courtyards, here particularly large and linked by steep flights of steps. [SEP] The walls of the first were once encrusted with inset porcelain plates, but many have been broken or lost. [SEP] Around Lake Batur

column1: lly thinning out into open pasture. [SEP] A band of rainforest blocks out the view until you emerge at 1,300 m (4,300 ft) on the narrow rim of a huge crater (technically a caldera or collapsed volcano), 11 km (7 miles) across and about 200 m (660 ft) deep. [SEP] The pastel blue crescent of Lake Batur takes up the eastern third of the great bowl, and out of the center grows Mount Batur itself, bare rock streaked with black traces of old lava flows. [SEP] Penelokan (“Place for Looking”) can offer a great panorama, but it’s an ugly village, at its worst when enveloped in a cold wet fog and you can’t see the view anyway. [SEP] The peddlers here are the most aggressive in Bali: Balinese travelers have complained about them since long before the arrival of tourists. [SEP] The height of confusion
column3: at lunchtime when the tour buses disgorge their passengers at the restaurants especially built for them. [SEP] Avoid the buffets which are often not fresh and notorious for making visitors ill. [SEP] There’s an even better view into the caldera, and no fuss, from the road a short way east from Penelokan (heading towards Suter and Rendang, the turnoff for Besakih).

column1: West of Denpasar Fertile land and high rainfall have brought prosperity to this part of Bali, without the debatable benefits of tourism. [SEP] In the main towns, you’ll find more computer suppliers than souvenir shops. [SEP] There is very little in the way of accommodations and not much choice when it
column3: to eating, but the region is rewarding to explore. [SEP] Mengwi

column1: North of Senggigi, the road is like one big giddy roller-coaster that passes some of the lovliest coastline in the Indonesian archipelago. [SEP] At times it climbs to the cliff tops, and then swoops down into bays. [SEP] Tiny fishing villages hide among the palm trees and the sea is flecked with bright lateen sails of prahus out after tuna and snapper. [SEP] Instead of the coast road, tours from Senggigi and traffic from Mataram sometimes take the inland route via the Pasuk Pass. [SEP] The two ways meet at Pemenang, where a side road leads to a harbor at Bangsal, the starting point for trips to the Gilis. [SEP] (Visitors often call them the Gili Islands, but gili means “island.”) [SEP] Gili Air is nearest, about 3 km (2 miles) away. [SEP] Next
column3: Gili Meno and then Gili Trawangan, the farthest out at 8 km (5 miles), and the biggest, although it’s only 21⁄2 km (11⁄2 miles) long. [SEP] The Gilis are known for their tranquility, surrounded by sparkling waters. [SEP] Snorkeling, diving, and sunning are the islands’ chief activities. [SEP] The boats that ply the route from Bangsal to the islands wait for a full load of 15 to 20 people. [SEP] In July and August that won’t take long, but out of season you can face a delay unless you pay for the empty places or charter a whole boat (fares are low and fixed).

column1: The city also subsidizes concerts, from rock to classical, in the Plaça de Catalunya and neighborhood parks. [SEP] One of the best events put on in the city is Grec, an annual festival of international dance, music, and theater. [SEP] From the last week of June to the end of the first week in August the cultural calendar is full of everything from American blues to Brazilian samba and avant-garde Belgian dance (for a schedule of events and ticket information: Tel. 93/301 77 75; <www .grecbcn.com>). [SEP] Barcelona is hardly Madrid or Seville when it
column3: to tablaos—live flamenco performances, though a few shows target the tourist trade: Tablao Flamenco Cordobés (Las Ramblas, 35; Tel. 93/317 66 53) is the most popular and predictable, while El Patio Andaluz (Aribau, 242; Tel 93/209 33 78) also puts on sevillanas, more traditional southern-style singing and dancing. [SEP] There are also flamenco shows twice nightly, except Monday, at El Tablao de Carmen in the Poble Espanyol on Montjuïc (Arcos, 9; tel. 93/325 68 95). [SEP] For one-stop partying among those interested more in convenience than quality, the Poble Espanyol features jazz clubs, flamenco performances, big-bands, theater, bars, and discos going strong until 4am.

column1: Sant Sadurní d’ Anoia (Penedès) Cava, Catalonia’s sparkling wine,
column3: from Penedès, a pretty spot 40 km (25 miles) from Barcelona with about four dozen wineries. [SEP] The French can’t be too happy about it, but the top-selling sparkling wine (a.k.a. champagne) in the world is a Catalan cava: Cordoniu and Freixenet. [SEP] The main town in the grape-growing region is Sant Sadurní d’ Anoia, where several top wineries are located and offer guided tours and tastings. [SEP] The most interesting is Codorniu, Spain’s largest producer of cava. [SEP] The visit to the family-owned winery is located on a spectacular campus, with buildings by Gaudí contemporary Puig i Cadafalch. [SEP] Completed in 1898, Codorniu has been declared a National Artistic and Historic Monument. [SEP] Besides the modernista architecture, visitors embark on a fun theme-park-like cart ride throug

column1: ody of Sun Yat-sen, founder of the modern Chinese Republic, once lay in state here before removal to Nanjing; his hat, coat, and coffin are still at this temple. [SEP] So, too, is the fascinating Luohan Hall. [SEP] Luohans are followers of Buddha who achieve enlightenment but choose to stay on Earth to show others the way. [SEP] The 500 luohans portrayed in this temple’s carved figures range from the ecstatic to the gruesome, from the common to the surreal. [SEP] Topping the temple is the Diamond Throne Pagoda (Jinggang Baozuo Ta), built in 1748 in the Indian style, with four pagodas and two stupas surrounding a 35-m (115-ft) white pagoda. [SEP] The most popular site in the Western Hills is natural: a summit known as Incense Burner Peak (Xiang Lu Feng), named for the image created when fog
column3: sweeping over it. [SEP] There is a winding path to the top known as Gui Jian Chou (“Even the Devil is Terrified”) as well as a chair lift (20 minutes each way). [SEP] At the 557-m (1,827-ft) summit there are pavilions, vendors, and small paths into surrounding forests. [SEP] There are also fine views of the lakes, temples, pavilions, and pagodas below, which can be explored upon return. [SEP] On a clear day, one is tempted to linger. [SEP] Here, there’s an emperor’s view to the southeast, commanding both the pavilions of the Summer Palace and the skyscrapers of downtown Beijing. [SEP] White Cloud Temple

column1: Theater When it
column3: to theater, Berlin is one of the most exciting and innovative cities in Europe and all the world, so that even without a great command of the German language, any enthusiastic theatergoer can enjoy some stirring performances. [SEP] In Germany major theaters often maintain several productions in repertory, so that in any one week you will be able to see the same troupe perform contemporary or classical drama. [SEP] There are over 150 theaters in the city, so there’s a vast range to choose from.

column1: The Zoo, entrance on Budapester Straße, has one of the most varied collections of animals in Europe. [SEP] Beyond the colorful and pagoda-arched Elefantentor (Elephant Gate) are 35 hectares (86 acres) of parkland where you will be able to observe Indian and African elephants, giant pandas from China, and the rare single-horned rhinoceros from India. [SEP] Sooner or later, everybody
column3: to promenade along the Ku’damm, and a suitable vantage point from which to survey them is Café Kranzler, a Berlin institution at the corner of Joachimstaler Straße. [SEP] It’s now decidedly bourgeois, although the original Kranzler at the west end of Unter den Linden between Friedrichstraße and the Brandenburg Gate was a hotbed of radical intellectuals in 1848. [SEP] The avenue lost almost all the Jugendstil architecture of its Wilhelminian heyday during World War II, but a vestige can be seen in the elegant Café Möhring just across the road. [SEP] Otherwise the street is resolutely modern — gleaming glass, steel, and an occasional touch of marble — but still a magnet for fashionable shopping.

column1: Musikinstrumentenmuseum Among the museum’s many historical musical instruments are a 1703 Stradivarius violin, the 1810 piano of composer Carl Maria von Weber, and a 1929 New York Wurlitzer cinema organ, which
column3: alive in a concert given at noon the first Saturday of every month. [SEP] Tours are conducted every Saturday at 11am. [SEP] Neue Nationalgalerie

column1: Pergamonmuseum The home of many impressive works of classical antiquity, the Near East, Islam, and the Orient, the museum is named after its most prized possession: the gigantic Pergamon Altar (2nd century b.c.). [SEP] This masterpiece of Hellenistic art
column3: from what is now Bergama, near the west coast of Turkey. [SEP] The massive colonnaded altar, which is dedicated to Zeus and Athena, has been constructed to fill one hall of the museum. [SEP] The Babylonian Processional Street (604–562 b.c.), built by King Nebuchadnezzar II, is equally impressive. [SEP] Lions sculpted in relief stride along the street’s blue-and- ochre tiled walls towards the Ishtar Gate. [SEP] The gate itself is decorated with bulls and dragons, also in blue-and-ochre tile.

column1: many activities, especially during the summer months. [SEP] A long row of pastel-painted buildings offer the best in tax-free shopping: jewelry, liquor, clothing, and crystal. [SEP] Explore the narrow alleyways that lead off Front Street to discover small shops selling collectibles or locally designed arts and crafts, or small restaurants offering local seafood. [SEP] On Front Street itself there are a number of restaurants with verandas on the first floor, where you can have a drink or meal and watch the world go by. [SEP] At the west end of Front Street, on the waterfront, you will find the Visitor Service Bureau and the terminal for the local ferries that ply across Great and Little Sound from Hamilton to the southern and western parts of Bermuda. [SEP] On summer evenings, Front Street
column3: alive with Harbour Night. [SEP] Street performers, craft stalls, and late-night shopping are all part of the festivities. [SEP] There is also the Beat Retreat Ceremony, where the Band and Corps of Drums of the Bermuda Regiment and the Bermuda Islands Pipe Band, in full military dress, march the street to recreate a centuries-old ceremony. [SEP] Most of Hamilton’s attractions can be seen on foot and would make an enjoyable day’s stroll. [SEP] But there is also the option of taking a carriage ride through the streets — there’s nothing more romantic than a horse-drawn carriage taking a stately route. [SEP] Carriages can be hired on Front Street during the summer season.

column1: ues signifying its ancient pedigree. [SEP] Inside, the bank keeps a collection of rare and valuable coins dating back through Bermuda’s history. [SEP] Every type of coin minted by the British crown can be found here, from the time of James I in 1603 (when the charter was granted that brought Bermuda’s first settlers) to the present day, including an example of “Hog” money. [SEP] Be sure to see the 1887 £5 coin, which caused consternation among British subjects of the time. [SEP] Because the crown pictured on Queen Victoria’s head was far too small, many people thought that the Queen (and, by extension, the empire) looked ridiculous. [SEP] From the bank, head for Queen Street, which leads north from the Birdcage, a metal cage once used by police officers to direct the traffic that regularly
column3: to a halt on Front Street. [SEP] It was designed by a Mr. Bird, although it also has a resemblance to “Tweetie Bird’s” cage. [SEP] Traffic lights now regulate the junction. [SEP] Remember to look right as you prepare to cross the road! [SEP] On the left as you walk up Queen Street is Perot Post Office, named after the man who was appointed Bermuda’s first Postmaster General in 1821. [SEP] He had actually been acting as “unofficial” postman for several years, meeting the ships and putting the letters under his hat before touring the town to deliver them. [SEP] William B. Perot (pronounced “Pea-rut”) went one stage further in 1848 when he began to produce his own postage stamps; only 11 are known to exist today, making each one extremely valuable. [SEP] The little Post Office is very much as

column1: Mid Ocean Golf Course and Castle Harbour Golf Course straddle the roads here, their verdant greens and fairways tumbling across the undulating land, separated by small casuarina copses. [SEP] (Be mindful of the state of play as you pass across the fairways here: there is a danger from flying or wayward balls!) [SEP] The Mid Ocean Club is still a private members’ club with a long pedigree. [SEP] It has played host to many important political summits since the end of World War II, including the “Big Three” Conference in 1953 attended by Winston Churchill, Dwight D. Eisenhower, and Joseph Laniel, the French prime minister. [SEP] South Road
column3: to an abrupt end at Tucker’s Town Bay, a small jetty and inlet with yachts bobbing gently in the water. [SEP] To get across Castle Harbour to St. George’s, you must go north here, taking Paynter’s Road to Harrington Sound. [SEP] Then drive up along Harrington Sound Road to reach the Causeway to St. George’s. [SEP] On your way up Harrington Sound Road, you will come to Lemington Caves, a series of caves smaller than Crystal Caves but equally spectacular. [SEP] Watch also for Walsingham Lane and a sign to Tom Moore’s Tavern, named after the Irish poet who spent some time on Bermuda. [SEP] The tavern (which is in fact a restaurant with French and local cuisine) is open only in the evening. [SEP] In the daytime you can visit Idwal Hughes Nature Reserve, also along Walsingham Lane — a pristine a

column1: This area bordering the eastern side of the common is filled with historical imprints and some of the city’s major architectural highlights, which are great when viewed from the harbor (see page 43). [SEP] Park Street Church stands on a site whose nickname
column3: from Brimstone Corner (some say for the fiery sermons delivered by such figures as Henry Ward Beecher and William Lloyd Garrison, who delivered his first anti-slavery speech here in 1829, others because gunpowder was kept in the basement during the 1812 War). [SEP] Built on the site of a granary in 1809, this Georgian church’s most beautiful feature is the 217-ft- (66-m-) tall triple-tiered steeple, based on a Christopher Wren design. [SEP] The adjacent Granary Burying Ground contains the graves of many heroes: John Hancock, Paul Revere, Samuel Adams, James Otis, the victims of the Boston Massacre, Robert Treat Paine (the prosecutor at the Boston Massacre trial), and Peter Faneuil. [SEP] A map near the entrance locates the gravestones of the famous. [SEP] Note the many headstones carved wit

column1: The first leader of the Magyars, Prince Arpád, founded a dynasty that lasted more than three centuries and introduced statehood to the new land. [SEP] Prince Géza, his great-grandson, embraced Christianity, and on the legendary date of Christmas Day a.d. 1000, Géza’s son, Steven (István), later St. Stephen (Szent István), was crowned the first king of Hungary in the city of Esztergom, situated on the Danube Bend. [SEP] The ﬁrst record of Pest, meaning “lime furnace” or “ovens” in Slavic,
column3: from 1061. [SEP] A landmark of the nation’s civilization in these early days, the Golden Bull of 1222 was a sort of “Magyar Carta” spelling out the rights of nobles and commoners alike. [SEP] But the rights of man were the last thing on the minds of the Mongols, who overran the country in 1241 and again in 1242. [SEP] Whole towns and villages, including Buda and Pest, were subjected to an orgy of killing and destruction. [SEP] The Mongols did not stay, however, nor did they return. [SEP] King Béla IV then set about reviving the wrecked nation, and founded the town of Buda, wisely building it within fortified walls. [SEP] The Angevin Dynasty

column1: el is the perfect place to recover from your walk. [SEP] Behind this classic 1918 white Art Nouveau structure is a swimming pool complex and the ﬁnest thermal bath in Buda. [SEP] While the older family members may wish to enjoy the restorative thermal waters and float at leisure in the beautiful indoor pool, youngsters will most likely delight in the equally splendid landscaped outdoor pool. [SEP] There are some more baths (fürdo) with a wonderful atmosphere in which to relax just along the Buda embankment (rakpart) by the entrance to the Erzsébet híd (Elizabeth Bridge). [SEP] The thermal pools are restricted to men, only. [SEP] The entrance to the Rudas fürdo is rather shabby, and a knowledge of the language is deﬁnitely an advantage here, but after 400 years of serving the locals, change
column3: slowly. [SEP] The building has been much altered over the centuries but the atmosphere in the steamy main pool, where a stone Turkish dome rises over an octagonal pool and sunbeams stream in through the star-shaped glass openings in the cupola, is magically ancient. [SEP] The medicinal theme continues a little farther north at the Semmelweis Museum of the History of Medicine (Semmelweis Orvostörténeti Múzeum). [SEP] Professor Semmelweis, who was born here in 1815, discovered the cause of puerperal fever and thus became known as the “Saviour of Mothers.” [SEP] The museum is a lively, sometimes gruesome, trawl through old instruments and techniques, some of which appear far worse than the condition they were intended to relieve. column1: Scuba diving. [SEP] There is marvelous scuba diving among the kelp forests of the coastline. [SEP] Some of the best centers are Monterey, Santa Barbara, La Jolla, and San Diego (Mission Bay Jetty), all of which offer equipment rental and instruction. [SEP] Sailing. [SEP] When it
column3: to sailing, San Diego is the place to go. [SEP] Every kind of vessel, from the smallest rowboat to the largest ocean-going yacht, is seen in the marinas of Mission Bay and around Shelter Island and Harbor Island in San Diego Bay. [SEP] The sheltered waters of Mission Bay are an ideal nursery for learning the basics of boat handling, while for the more experienced and adventurous sailors the wide Pacific waits outside. [SEP] Sailing instruction and boat rentals — rowboats and power boats, sailing dinghies, and yachts — are all available at Mission Bay, San Diego; Marina del Rey, Los Angeles; in Santa Barbara; and in Sausalito. [SEP] Fishing. [SEP] Sea angling can be enjoyed from the rocks and piers along the coastline, while deep-sea fishing is available from the sailing harbors listed above

column1: From the Parc de l’Esplanade, drive up the Côte de la Citadelle hill road and through a tunnel for a guided tour around a powerful bastion of fears long gone. [SEP] The French built the starshaped Citadel in 1750 to resist the British. [SEP] The British enlarged it in 1820 to defend Québec City against the Americans, but their cannons never fired a shot in anger. [SEP] The garrison was British-manned for only 20 years before being handed over to Canadian troops. [SEP] Today it is the home of Canada’s crack Royal 22nd Regiment. [SEP] In summertime the garrison
column3: to life with the Changing of the Guard (10am daily, June 24–first week of Sept.) and Beating the Retreat (6pm Wed–Sat during July and August). [SEP] The old powder house serves now as the Musée Militaire, displaying the regiment’s history with its trophies, weapons, and uniforms. [SEP] Running southwest from the Parc de l’Esplanade, the broad, modern Grande-Allée runs past the Assemblée Nationale (provincial parliament), built from 1877–1886 in the favored style of the time, French Renaissance. [SEP] This has been the citadel of Québec’s quest for a special identity in or outside the Canadian Confederation, especially under Prime Minister René Lévesque.

column1: St. John’s Local folklore insists that the name (not to be confused with Saint John, New Brunswick)
column3: from the saint’s day of John the Baptist, June 24, when John Cabot arrived here in 1497. [SEP] Newfoundland’s capital and largest city retains the simple allure of the fishing port it has always been, and the picturesque harbor is the place to begin. [SEP] In the 19th century the town burned down five times, but it still stubbornly builds wooden houses overlooking the waterfront. [SEP] Their brightly painted walls add a welcome touch of color to the gaunt grey trawlers in the docks — from Britain, of course, but also Russia and even Japan. [SEP] Parallel to the harbor, you’ll find on Gower Street the prettiest Victorian houses, painted burgundy, lemon, burnt sienna, dove grey, and white.

column1: THE ROCKIES AND PRAIRIES In this region, the great Canadian outdoors really
column3: into its own. [SEP] The national parks of the Rocky Mountains provide unrivaled opportunities for exhilarating contacts with a wilderness where you can really escape from your fellow man: camping and hiking through the forests; fishing in the myriad lakes and rivers; canoeing and whitewater rafting in the mountain torrents. [SEP] And skiing, downhill and cross-country, has been greatly enhanced by the ultra-modern facilities installed for Calgary’s 1988 Winter Olympics. [SEP] Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba form the Prairie Provinces, sharing the same rugged climate. [SEP] The full meaning of Canada’s “wide open spaces” be

column1: The Rest of the Island From Valverde follow the road to Isora, a neat little village of well-tended gardens. [SEP] There are three miradors to enjoy on the road to El Pinar. [SEP] The name
column3: from the pinewood forests that in places make up a gentle rolling landscape of fields and trees reminiscent of northern Europe. [SEP] As the road descends south the greenery eventually peters out into volcanic badlands, and at the tip of the island is the fishing port of La Restinga. [SEP] The switchback road down to Frontera passes fertile cultivated fields and the occasional disused lagar (winepress). [SEP] The bell tower of the church here is something of an oddity, being divorced from its body and set on top of a small hill next to it. [SEP] From a distance the tiny tower set against the massive cliff side seems terribly remote, but as you approach it the illusion disappears and the main road passes within feet of the church and tower. column1: A few miles north of La Santa, home to the Club La Santa a time-share development resort where athletes of the highest level come for both training and relaxation, is the tiny village of Caleta de Famara. [SEP] It has windswept beaches with views of the daunting cliffs of the Famara Massif that lead up to the Mirador del Río and Graciosa island. [SEP] There is not much to do along this coastline except sunbathe and windsurf, but as the currents can be dangerous here, be sure to take care. [SEP] Teguise is a fine old town of cobbled streets and gracious mansions and was the island capital until 1852. [SEP] Now it is calm and quiet for six days of the week. [SEP] On Sundays a handicrafts market

[SEP] Several of its old buildings have been converted to craft and antique shops and restaurants. [SEP] Overlooking the town is the 16th-century Castillo de Santa Bárbara. [SEP] The views from this wind-blown point are worth the trip alone. [SEP] High on top of the extinct volcano of Guanapay, the castle now hosts the Museo del Emigrante Canario, where sepia photos and nostalgic exhibits tell the sad story of how mass emigration to South America was the only option left for many Canarian families. [SEP] Costa Teguise, just north of Arrecife, is a totally modern resort, comprising several urbanizaciónes with time-shares, hotels, and apartments designed for a wealthy clientele. [SEP] It is

column1: opular with nudists. [SEP] The island lies 3 km (2 miles) offshore, and its beaches are even more secluded than those on the “mainland.” [SEP] The fishing here is outstanding. [SEP] Glass-bottomed ferry-boats depart regularly from Corralejo. [SEP] The rest of the route to Puerto del Rosario, once named Puerto Cabras (Port of the Goats) because in the 18th century it was used mainly for the raising of goats, has nothing of interest for tourists and the town itself is a rather drab place. [SEP] The inland route south to Puerto del Rosario follows the FV-101 and a diversion, west along the FV-109 will bring you first to the Zoo Safari Calderón Hondo. [SEP] There you can opt for either a half-hour camel trip or a 11⁄2 hour safari to the lunar landscape of the Volcano Calderón Hondo. [SEP] Next
column3: the lace-making town of Lajares. [SEP] And if you really want to get away from it all, continue on to El Cotillo. [SEP] This tiny fishing village on the east coast also boasts some excellent beaches wonderful for windsurfing, plus a handful of local bars and some basic restaurants. [SEP] Heading back south from El Cotillo, the FV-10 rejoins the FV-101 at the small town of La Oliva. [SEP] This is not especially attractive but it does feature two places of interest. [SEP] Just off the main road stands the Casa de los Coroneles (House of the Colonels). [SEP] Its name derives from its 18th-century tenants who once ruled the island. [SEP] The decaying, cream-colored building still exudes a certain haughty, if melancholy, grandeur. [SEP] By contrast, the nearby Centro de Arte Canario is bright an

[SEP] You will also find a book and gift store, a restaurant, and a museum with finds from the site and a model of the city to help you to get your bearings. [SEP] As you enter the site (in the new part of the city) the huge square edifice of El Castillo, also called the Pyramid of Kukulkán,
column3: into view on your right. [SEP] The pyramid, 30 m (100 ft) high and the main time-keeping mechanism of the city, was built very precisely in position, shape, and height in order to predict the planting and harvesting cycles. [SEP] There are 364 steps in four staircases, which together represent the 365 days of the year. [SEP] There are 52 panels on each side, which echo the 52-year cycle of the Mayan calendar, and terraces that parallel the main staircase, representing the 18-month solar cycle. [SEP] The best time to see this super-sized timepiece in action is at the Spring Equinox (21 March) or Fall Equinox (21 September) in the afternoon, when the sun’s rays fall down the northern stairway and hit the serpent head at the base. column1: the very start of the Spanish occupation, on the site of a large Mayan city, T’Ho. [SEP] Mérida became the focus of influence for the Montejo family, who exerted their force over the surrounding countryside. [SEP] Since that time, it has seen the ebb and flow of economic prosperity and political power, yet its architecture and lifestyle — a total contrast to modern Cancún — make it a fascinating place to visit. [SEP] Mérida is a vibrant, bustling city with a tangible energy. [SEP] It also has interesting attractions that can fill a few days of your itinerary. [SEP] The heart of the city is Plaza Major (also known by a variety of names such as Plaza des Armas, Plaza Principal, Plaza de la Independencia, and Plaza de la Revolucion). [SEP] Its tree-lined center has shaded seats where everyone
column3: to meet and talk; shoe-shine boys work throughout the day, while ice-cream sellers stand on street corners with their small barrows. [SEP] Look out for the confidenciales, or love seats, where courting couples could sit next to each other without compromising the woman’s reputation. [SEP] In the center of the square is a flagpole supporting a Mexican flag, which is raised and lowered at the start and end of each day (6am and 6pm) in an elaborate ceremony undertaken by the local police band. [SEP] Numerous historic buildings, dating back to the very earliest days of Spanish rule, line the square and its surrounding grid of streets. [SEP] Construction of many of these buildings used stones from the Mayan city of T’Ho, so, alas, nothing remains of this site. [SEP] Perhaps the most important bu

column1: The Forbidden City, so described because it was off-limits to ordinary people for nearly 500 years, is now called the Palace Museum. [SEP] Designed to contain the auspicious number of 9,999 rooms, its scale is overwhelming and leaves many visitors bewildered. [SEP] Built in the years 1406–1420, it was the residence of 24 emperors for nearly seven centuries. [SEP] Tourists normally enter the Forbidden City from the south, after a long walk along a cobbled roadway from the Gate of Heavenly Peace. [SEP] The main entrance to the compound, Meridian Gate (Wumen), was designed in the 15th century. [SEP] Officials used the left portal, members of the imperial family the right. [SEP] Next
column3: another ceremonial gate, the Gate of Supreme Harmony (Taihemen), first erected in 1420. [SEP] A pair of monumental bronze lions stand guard. [SEP] Beyond this powerful defense line stands China’s supreme ensemble of ancient architecture. [SEP] First and foremost is the Hall of Great Harmony (Taihedian), popularly called the “Hall of the Imperial Throne.” [SEP] This is the biggest building in the Forbidden City and one of China’s most beautiful wooden structures. [SEP] For hundreds of years during the Ming and Qing dynasties this was the tallest building in all Beijing; by law no house could rise higher. [SEP] (Counting the hall’s upswept roof decorations, that meant the limit was approximately 371⁄2 m, or 123 ft.) [SEP] Inside, on a raised platform, the “Son of Heaven” sat on his Dragon Thr

column1: On the way to the Great Wall is the peaceful valley the Ming emperors chose as their burial ground. [SEP] In 1407 the Emperor Yongle ordered a search for a suitable burial place with auspicious “wind and water” conditions, as well as appropriate grandeur. [SEP] This site proved so perfect that all but three of the succeeding Ming rulers were entombed in the same valley. [SEP] The Sacred Way to the Ming Tombs begins at a great marble gateway more than four centuries old. [SEP] Beyond this is the main gate with three archways; the middle arch was used only once in each reign — for the delivery of the emperor’s remains to his tomb. [SEP] Then
column3: the Avenue of the Animals, which is lined with massive statues of real and mythical beasts. [SEP] The largest tomb (Changling) belonged to Yongle himself. [SEP] Its Hall of Eminent Favors (Lingendian) is among the largest wooden buildings in China. [SEP] The 32 gilded pillars supporting the coffered ceiling were fashioned from a huge tree that took more than five years to ship here from southwest China.

column1: Sightseeing Guangzhou can’t claim to compete with Beijing or Xi’an when it
column3: to sightseeing attractions. [SEP] But its monuments and parks are well worth visiting, not least for the chance to mingle with the Cantonese people themselves. [SEP] Yue Xiu Park, near the Trade Fair in the northern part of the city, covers a 93-hectare (230-acre) site. [SEP] In addition to its pretty gardens, lakes, pavilions, and sports facilities, Guangzhou’s largest park also contains the city’s oldest building, the red “Tower Overlooking the Sea” (Zhenhailou). [SEP] Actually, “tower” is a misleading description for this building of five stories. [SEP] Built in 1380, it now houses the municipal museum (Guangzhou Bowuguan). [SEP] With signs in English and Chinese, the museum is quite interesting and includes artifacts and displays recording the city’s contacts with the West (from Bibles

column1: The climate is subtropical, with an annual rainfall of 190 cm (75 inches), so avoid the rainiest season, from April through July. [SEP] An additional incentive for visiting in autumn is the sight and fragrance of osmanthus (cassia) blossoms all over town; in fact, the name Guilin means “Cassia Woods.” [SEP] Tourists are so numerous in the otherwise relaxed shopping district of Guilin that the pedestrian crossings have signs in English as well as Chinese. [SEP] Another cosmopolitan influence
column3: from the area’s many minority peoples: Guilin is part of the Guangxi-Zhuang Autonomous Region, which borders Vietnam. [SEP] The proliferation of so-called Muslim restaurants is explained by the presence here of thousands of people of the traditionally Muslim Zhuang nationality, China’s largest minority group. [SEP] The geological history of Guilin, the key to the wonder of its moody mountains and caves, goes back several hundred million years. [SEP] The area was under the sea when an upheaval raised it to the status of terra firma. [SEP] Later it was flooded, then lifted again in further cataclysmic events. [SEP] The alternation of sea water and air through the millennia created limestone formations called karst, which eroded into pinnacles, mounds, and peaks that captivate the imagination.

column1: a thousand years ago to write: “The river is a green silk belt, the mountains emerald hairpins.” [SEP] Peaks and pinnacles crowd the river, white goats pose on steep mountainsides, and an eagle soars above the cliffs. [SEP] The river itself flows green and transparent. [SEP] Credit for this limpid rarity goes not only to the strict antipollution standards to protect the River Li but also to nature itself, which endows the water with a high content of carbonic acid. [SEP] Mural Hill is so called because the sheer cliff face comprises so many patches of color that it might be a fresco. [SEP] In the lights and shadows of the cliff, the shapes of nine different horses can be discerned, hence the cliff’s alternate name, “Nine Horse Hill.” [SEP] Near the end of the voyage, the village of Xinping
column3: into view on the left bank, surrounded by magical scenery — landmarks with names like Snail Hill, Five Fingers Hill, and Carp Hill. [SEP] The boat trips end at the county town of Yangshuo, a favorite of poets and painters and a destination in its own right. [SEP] The distance traversed by river is a mere 83 km (52 miles), but there is no river trip like it. [SEP] The trip back to Guilin by bus provides yet another facet to the soaring scenery.

column1: At the summit, where the altitude is 223 m (732 ft), the charmingly named Catch-Cloud Pavilion (Nayunting) provides a 360-degree panorama. [SEP] The view is worth savoring: the winding river, the tile-roofed cityscape, the green flat farmland, and the surreal hills forever popping up near and far. [SEP] Closer to the city center is Fuboshan (“Whirlpool Hill”) another natural stone tower with a view as well as other distractions. [SEP] According to legend, a General Fubo, who passed this way 2,000 years ago, tested his sword in the Sword-Testing Stone, a stalactite formation that
column3: down to within inches of the ground. [SEP] Further on, the Thousand Buddha Cliff is carved with several hundred figures dating from the Tang and Song dynasties. [SEP] The District of the Two Lakes, in the southern part of town, has been made into a delightful public park with gardens, walkways, and pagodas. [SEP] Originally, Banyan Tree Lake (Ronghu) and Fir Tree Lake (Shahu) were a single expanse, forming part of the moat which protected the city wall. [SEP] The Song Dynasty-era Green Belt Bridge across the middle created the two lakes.

column1: Huangshan (Hwang Shan) Although “Yellow Mountain” is the literal translation of Huangshan (which is not one mountain but a range of dozens of peaks), yellow is not the color that first
column3: to mind when describing this romantic site that has been the subject of Chinese poetry and painting for centuries. [SEP] In reality, green is the color of the stunted pines clinging to purple cliff faces. [SEP] Pink are the wildflowers, blue the sky, and white the sea of clouds that rolls in beneath the rocky pinnacles. [SEP] Huangshan is the only region of eastern China’s Anhui Province that appears on major tourist itineraries. [SEP] Trains and planes link Shanghai with a terminus at the foot of the mountains, where coaches continue the journey. [SEP] The scenic mountain resort now has hotel facilities, from extremely basic to comfortable. [SEP] Chinese tourists — and poets — might spend a week or more exploring the mountains, but foreign visitors try to squeeze it all into a day or two.

column1: e whole region, these tunnels, all dug by hand, stretch for perhaps 3,000 km (more than 1,800 miles), with some singular water tunnels running as far as 40 km (25 miles). [SEP] Thanks to the wells, Turpan grows cotton, melons, and grapes of great sweetness and renown. [SEP] And the surrounding desert is kept at bay by bountifully irrigated stands of elm, poplar, and palm trees. [SEP] The karez is an engineering feat on par with that of the Grand Canal, and an exhibition center at one well site allows visitors to enter several of these hand-dug wells for a close-up view. [SEP] The climatic conditions of China’s “oven” are nevertheless hostile to humans. [SEP] In the summer, when the temperature exceeds 40°C (104°F) for days at a time, the locals take refuge in cellars until the night breeze
column3: up. [SEP] In the springtime, when the mercury is merely in the 30s (close to 90°F), the people dress for a chill — the men in their long underwear and the women in thick brown stockings and gaily colored headscarves. [SEP] Turpan is about 200 km (125 miles) southeast of Urumqi, the regional capital. [SEP] It’s so dry and (except for winter) hot in the oasis that tourists are advised to drink as much tea or juice as possible to forestall dehydration. [SEP] Laundry on the line dries in a matter of minutes rather than hours or days.

column1: Each phase of the fight is closely controlled by the presidente, from his flag-draped box. [SEP] He drops two handkerchiefs, one to signal the swaggering parade that precedes the fight, and the other to release the first bull from the puerta de toriles, the matador’s “gate of fear,” for the opening act or first tercio. [SEP] The bull is played with magenta capes — first by the matador’s team, or cuadrilla, then by the matador himself. [SEP] All the time the torero is assessing the bull, noting his temperament, how he charges, and how he uses his horns. [SEP] The picador’s moment
column3: during the second tercio, when he rides into the ring on a horse protected by padding. [SEP] His task is to lance the bull’s huge shoulder muscles; it’s unattractive but necessary, both to weaken the bull and to lower his head for the kill. [SEP] Too much lance, and the picador ruins the fight. [SEP] Too little, and he gives the torero an impossible task. [SEP] Now banderillas — long, ribboned, steel-tipped darts — are plunged into the bull’s shoulders. [SEP] In a moment of grace and athleticism, the banderillero, or even the matador himself, runs obliquely across the path of the bull, barely pausing as he jack-knifes over the horns to thrust home the darts.

[SEP] Then there is langosta — spiny lobster — as succulent and as expensive as ever, and sometimes priced per 100 grammes (be sure to read the menu’s small print to make sure). [SEP] Gambas are prawns, and langostinos the jumbo-sized version. [SEP] Try them a la plancha (grilled), a la romana (fried in batter), or al pil pil in a hot spicy sauce. [SEP] Emperador (swordfish) is especially good grilled, and lenguado (sole) is delicious in batter, grilled, or sautéed in butter. [SEP] For something different, try dorada a la sal: a whole fish is packed in wet salt, then baked. [SEP] It
column3: to the table in a shiny white jacket that is broken when the fish is cut and served. [SEP] These seafood dishes tend to be rather expensive, but there are some cheaper options. [SEP] Try calamares (squid), for instance; they are marvellous deep-fried (a la romana), stuffed (rellenos), or cooked in their own ink (en su tinta). [SEP] Mejillones (mussels) can be remarkably good steamed with a dash of white wine and garlic. [SEP] Caballa, the rich-fleshed mackerel, is sometimes available ahumada (smoked).

column1: Tapas A tapa is a mouthful of anything that tastes good and fits on a cocktail stick. [SEP] The variety is enormous: smoked mountain ham, spicy sausages, cheese, olives (some as big as pigeon’s eggs), sardines, mushrooms, mussels, squid, octopus, meatballs, fried fish, plus sauces and exotic-looking specialities of the house. [SEP] The name
column3: from the practice, sadly almost vanished, of providing a free bite with every drink. [SEP] The tidbit was put on a small plate traditionally used to cover the glass and came to be called a tapa, which means lid. [SEP] Touring tapas bars is great fun, especially in a town’s old quarter. [SEP] It can be expensive, certainly more than the cost of an orthodox meal, but do try to devote at least an evening to it. [SEP] The code is simple: one helping is called a porción; a large serving is a ración; half as much, a media-ración.

column3: to variety, few resort areas in the world can compare with the Costa del Sol. [SEP] There are nearly 30 18-hole courses between Málaga and Gibraltar. [SEP] Most private and hotel clubs welcome non-residents or non-members, though some may charge visitors a higher fee. [SEP] Clubs, caddies, and carts are generally available for rental. [SEP] The quality of the courses is excellent — many have been designed by such famous names as Robert Trent Jones and Seve Ballesteros. [SEP] Las Brisas, near Marbella, has hosted the Spanish Open and Valderrama, near Sotogrande, was host to the 1997 Ryder Cup. [SEP] Although a private club, Valderrama has nine starting times between midday and 2pm that are open to the public, albeit at 30,000 ptas (a180.3) per round.

column1: Where to Go Most visitors to the Costa del Sol are based in one of the large coastal resorts to the west of Málaga (Torremolinos, Benalmádena, Fuengirola, Marbella or Estepona), while far fewer head east toward Nerja, Almuñécar, or even as far as Almería. [SEP] Although the main aim for many is to relax on the beach and soak up as much sun as possible, increasing numbers arrive to play golf. [SEP] It
column3: as little surprise, therefore, that the road signs proclaim the area west of Málaga not just the Costa del Sol, but the Costa del Golf also. [SEP] A few visitors forsake the beach for a day or two and venture out to either the amazingly varied historic towns and cities or the natural wonders of the national parks nearby. [SEP] Málaga, Ronda, and perhaps Gibraltar can be seen in a day, but Sevilla, Córdoba, Granada, and the parks necessitate at least an overnight stop.

column1: has an ancient history. [SEP] A fine aqueduct stands as a monument to the skills of the Roman engineers who constructed it during the reign of Antoninus Pius in the second century a.d. A port for Granada in Moorish times, Almuñécar continued to enjoy a certain prestige after the Reconquest when Juan de Herrera, the architect of El Escorial, Philip II’s grand monastery cum palace near Madrid, was commissioned to design the parish church. [SEP] These days the town, set around an attractive curving beach, is an increasingly popular family resort. [SEP] Along the road from Almuñécar, pretty villas with spectacular coastal views dot the hillsides until, all of a sudden, the scenery changes dramatically. [SEP] As the coast flattens out, a town of whitewashed houses atop a rocky, cone-shaped hill
column3: into view. [SEP] Called Salobreña, it makes for an impressive sight. [SEP] A Moorish castle, beautifully restored, stands isolated at the heart of the village. [SEP] Salobreña stands as the gateway to the agriculturally rich vega (plain) of the thriving port city of Motril. [SEP] Sugarcane, the source of the greenery, flourishes here. [SEP] The sugar refineries in the area have earned the town its nickname — Little Cuba. [SEP] Like that country, Motril is known for its rum, although its residents are crafty enough to make just about enough for local consumption, and no more. [SEP] Motril and Salobreña have their own extensive beaches and there are many more to come as the road continues eastward.

column1: Iráklion Iráklion
column3: as a surprise to travelers used to Greek islands further north in the Aegean Sea. [SEP] It is a true city bustling with activity, dust, and noise. [SEP] The commercial and administrative heart of Crete, its streets are filled with bankers and business people. [SEP] There is a lively young scene based around the university, and a sophistication to match other major Greek cities such as Athens or Thessalonica. [SEP] However, this is not the only facet of the city. [SEP] Around the harbor you’ll still find a fishing industry based on small family-owned boats, and small workshops in the narrow back streets that still manufacture by hand. [SEP] Though there are many modern buildings, these sit shoulder to shoulder with fine old mansions and are evidence of an older Iráklion, which is fascinating

column1: The North Coast The Costa Blanca’s reputation for magnificent beaches and lively resorts
column3: from the northern stretch of coast. [SEP] Take the N-332 from Alicante and drive through Campello to the fishing port of Villajoyosa. [SEP] This picturesque village, some 30 km (18 miles) from the provincial capital, is more authentically Spanish in character than Benidorm, its cosmopolitan neighbour. [SEP] Wind your way towards the sea through the narrow streets of the old town, and suddenly you’ll see a group of housefronts in sun-bleached blues, pinks, and yellows. [SEP] White-rimmed doors and windows, black wrought-iron grilles, green blinds, and a massive Gothic church give the impression of a sparkling diadem — but then Villajoyosa literally means “Jewelled Town.”

column1: The next stop is Tárbena (10 km/6 miles farther along the C-3318), an invigorating mountain village famed for its delicious sausages. [SEP] They’re made from a secret recipe handed down to the present-day villagers by their Mallorcan ancestors, who came here in the early 17th century as part of an official repopulation scheme. [SEP] After Tárbena
column3: the finest scenery of all: bold, terraced mountains, wide undulating valleys, and scattered farms connected by mule tracks. [SEP] In spring the countryside is covered with the pink and white of almond blossoms, but the road is for all seasons, with groves of gnarled olive trees alongside it, their leaves blowing silver in the evening light. [SEP] Follow the road to Coll de Rates, 500 metres (1,500 feet) above the wide orange- and vine-filled plains that sweep up to Jávea, Denia, Gandía, and the deep-blue Mediterranean. [SEP] Farther on, take the road to Jalon, where in late summer farmers sell muscat grapes to passers-by, and you can buy some of the strong local wine. [SEP] Or carry on past Orba to Benidoleig and visit the prehistoric caves, Las Calaveras. [SEP] Here high-domed ceilings dri

column1: Thousands of pines, palms, and eucalyptus trees, planted to control shifting sand dunes, shade the beaches at Guardamar del Segura (17 km/10 miles south again on the N-332), an important fishing centre. [SEP] Spiny lobsters are a speciality of Guardamar restaurants. [SEP] From here, the road travels a further 15 km (9 miles), past the salt flats of La Mata, to Torrevieja. [SEP] The long-vanished “old tower” from which Torrevieja took its name has been replaced by a new one, built with funds raised by expatriate citizens. [SEP] The expanding summer resort and its long, sandy beaches co-exist with Europe’s largest and oldest salt industry. [SEP] The enormous mountain of salt you’ll see
column3: from the La Mata and Torrevieja pans. [SEP] Visitors are welcome Tuesdays and Thursdays from 5:00 p.m. [SEP] Request passes from the office of the Nueva Compañía Arrendataria de las Salinas de Torrevieja on the port’s main square. [SEP] (Photography permits are harder to get.) [SEP] In August Torrevieja pulsates to the music of the Habaneras festival. [SEP] The theme is the lively, song form of the same name (remember Bizet’s Carmen?), brought back from Cuba during the 19th-century salt-export voyages. [SEP] The festivities include musical competitions, concerts, and shows by leading — sometimes international — companies.

column1: Five km (3 miles) more bring you to thriving Mojácar, a village planted on the eastern extremity of the rugged Sierra Cabrera. [SEP] Purists complain that the cubist effect of steep hillsides dotted with square, flat-roofed houses has been spoiled by modern development, but the beaches all around are still pleasant. [SEP] About 3,000 years ago, Mojácar was an important Phoenician port, but earthquakes and major geological upheavals have left it high and dry. [SEP] For centuries the women of Mojácar were kept behind the veil, and the place is still known as the “Village of the Covered Ones.” (Interestingly, there’s an elegant white statue of a veiled woman outside the church.) Its renown as the “Village of Witches”
column3: from Mojácar’s long and continuing flirtation with faith healing, spells, and magic brews. [SEP] This isolated town is the last bastion of the mystical sign of the dalo, a figure holding a rainbow over his head that was believed to be a talisman against the evil eye. [SEP] (The word

column1: d increasingly more comfortable trailside lodges that can be found on the major trekking routes. [SEP] By staying in lodges, you avoid having to carry a tent, food, or cooking gear. [SEP] A luxury trek in the first category might cost $100 or more per day per person. [SEP] Hiring a guide and porter will lower your daily costs to somewhere around $20 or $25, while going it alone (meaning without a guide, as trekking without any companion should not be attempted) can be done for less than $10 a day. [SEP] October and November are the most popular trekking months because they are warm and sunny, and the trails are dry after the monsoon. [SEP] December is good for low-level treks, though it will be getting cold at higher altitudes. [SEP] The winter months bring the clearest skies. [SEP] Spring
column3: in March and April, when rhododendrons and other flowers set the forests ablaze with color. [SEP] In spring the skies gradually become hazy and there are light rains, which can make flights to starting points unpredictable. [SEP] By May it is hot in Pokhara, the high peaks are rarely visible, and humidity mounts until the weather breaks in June, with the onset of the monsoon. [SEP] Trails during the monsoon are muddy, slippery, and leech-ridden, which makes trekking between June and October a miserable experience. [SEP] It is possible to fly to higher elevations where leeches are less of a problem, but the rainclouds make mountain flights particularly dangerous. [SEP] Deciding where to go will depend on the time available and your physical condition. [SEP] Serious trekkers usually plan on s

column1: rgency first aid on local villagers, but aside from putting a bandage and disinfectant on someone’s cut, you may just want to direct the injured and infirm to the nearest health post, unless you have a medical background, can adequately diagnose the problem, and have the appropriate remedy handy. [SEP] Staying properly hydrated is perhaps the most difficult thing on a trek. [SEP] Carry a canteen and some iodine or a two-stage water filter (one that iodizes the water), and try to drink at least two quarts (liters) of water a day to avoid dehydration. [SEP] Alternatively, taking lots of tea breaks and ordering tea by the pot rather than just by the glass will help to keep plenty of liquids in you. [SEP] Avoid buying the bottled water sold along the trail. [SEP] The plastic bottles this water
column3: in have become the most prevalent form of litter along the trails in recent years, and to make things even worse, they are sometimes just refilled from a nearby water tap and resold to unsuspecting trekkers. [SEP] If you are on an organized trek, carry plenty of small rupee notes in case you want to buy some tea, a Coke, or some other snack or souvenir along the trail. [SEP] If you are doing a lodge-to-lodge trek, carry plenty of 20, 50, and 100 rupee notes.

column1: . [SEP] On 14 April, a huge pole, decorated with leaves and garlands and two streamers representing snakes, is erected in a field on the outskirts. [SEP] Why snakes? [SEP] Well, it seems that a princess of bygone years required a new lover every night because each morning her partner was found dead. [SEP] Finally a prince took on the job, and after satisfying the princess he hid himself, sword bared. [SEP] Two snakes issued from the princess’s nostrils, ready to kill. [SEP] But the prince hacked them up and lived happily ever after with the princess — no questions asked. [SEP] Her father, the king, ordered the pole with snake streamers to be erected every year in commemoration. [SEP] A second tug of war takes place on New Year’s afternoon, when the pole is pulled by opposing teams until it
column3: crashing down. [SEP] Indra Jatra is an important festival, usually falling in early September. [SEP] During this week-long observance, the Kumari is drawn through the streets of Kathmandu on her chariot and receives the homage of the king. [SEP] Ritual dances are staged in Durbar Square, which is jam-packed at this time, the steps of the Vishnu temple being reserved for women and children decked out in their finest. [SEP] On the last evening, the screen is removed from the face of the White Bhairav mask and beer squirts from his mouth to the jostling crowd beneath.

column1: Patan’s big blow-out, in late April, is in honor of the Red Machendra, a god sacred to both Buddhists and Hindus and probably of very ancient origin among valley animists. [SEP] The festival involves dragging a huge chariot across the city and sometimes takes a month before culminating in the display of a jeweled vest, about which, needless to say, another complicated legend exists. [SEP] Kathmandu’s White Machendra gets his chariot ride a month earlier. [SEP] Holi, when a kind of maypole with streamers is put up in Basantapur Chowk next to Kathmandu’s old royal palace and crowds throw colored powders and water bags at each other,
column3: in March–April, the merriment encouraged by the full moon. [SEP] Gaijatra, the festival of cows and departed souls, is another light-hearted celebration. [SEP] Departed souls who hold onto the tails of cows are believed to receive assistance in entering heaven. [SEP] Boys dressed as cows and clowns dance in the streets, and much alcohol is consumed, especially in Bhaktapur. [SEP] During a year after the death of a family member, Nepalis wear white in mourning. [SEP] White candles also are used at the time of death. [SEP] Trekkers who reach the Thyangboche Monastery above Namche Bazaar on the full-moon day of November will be privileged to see the Buddhist monks’ masked dance ceremony, Mani Rimdu. [SEP] A similar dance takes place on the May–June full moon. [SEP] Sherpas celebrate Tibetan Ne

column1: angur monkeys leap and swing in the treetops, sending flights of green parakeets screeching. [SEP] In open glades, peacocks preen, and shy, tiny barking deer, no taller than the peacocks, race away at an intruder’s approach. [SEP] It’s a magical environment. [SEP] The best way to see the wildlife, and certainly the most fun, is swaying atop a silently padding elephant. [SEP] The elephant grass along the several rivers in the park is so tall that only from an elephant’s back can you spot rhinos, deer, and other creatures, most of which are used to seeing elephants and do not run from them. [SEP] With luck, you’ll see a leopard draped indolently on a tree branch, and perhaps a stately sambar stag. [SEP] Spotted deer, sloth bear, giant flying squirrels, and civet cats are among the other mammals the visitor may see. [SEP] There are several jungle lodges and tented camps within the park’s boundaries, and from any of these camps there is a very high likelihood that you will see rhinos and deer. [SEP] Tigers, leopards, and sloth bears are a bit more elusive. [SEP] All of these lodges, and even some outside the park, have their own elephants and nature guides. [SEP] On a stay at one of these lodges, a half day is usually spent in dug-out canoes searching for endangered gharials, a narrow jawed fish-eating crocodile, and their flesh-eating cousins, the huge marsh muggers. [SEP] It was here that St. Denis was martyred (see page 13) and where St. Ignatius Loyola launched the Jesuit movement in 1534. [SEP] The funicular (it takes métro and bus tickets) climbs to the terrace in front of the Byzantine-style basilica of Sacré-Cœur. [SEP] Standing at the highest point in Paris, it’s one of the city’s principal landmarks, and one of the few to remain perennially controversial. [SEP] Artists still scorn it as a vulgar pastiche, and the working-class residents of the area resented its being erected as a symbol of penitence for the insurrection of the 1871 Commune — they didn’t feel penitent in the least. [SEP] The Sacré-Cœur’s conspicuous whiteness
column3: from the local Château-Landon limestone, which bleaches on contact with carbon dioxide in the air and hardens with age. [SEP] For many, the best reason for visiting the basilica is the view of the city from the dome or the terrace below. [SEP] Just a few steps west of Sacré-Cœur is St-Pierre-de-Montmartre, one of the city’s oldest churches. [SEP] Consecrated in 1147, 16 years before the church of St-Germain-des-Prés (see page 58), it is a significant work of early Gothic, belied by its 18th-century façade. [SEP] The Sacré-Cœur’s architect, Paul Abadie, wanted to demolish St-Pierre, but he was overruled, and it was restored “as a riposte to the Sacré-Cœur.”

[SEP] Embroidery. [SEP] A great many embroidered, items, including tablecloths and napkins, are all over Portugal — especially at street markets. [SEP] Look for the delicate hand needlework that

[SEP] Filigree work, a legacy of the Moors, is of extremely high quality. [SEP] Look for silver filigree earrings and brooches, often in the form of flowers or butterflies.

column1: Access from one part of the Algarve to another is along the EN125 road, which runs most of the length of the coast. [SEP] The section of coast stretching from Faro eastwards to Spain, known as the Sotavento Coast, is made up of salt marshes and lagoons, with beautiful sandy beaches on the barrier islands just offshore. [SEP] The most intensively developed part stretches westward from Faro to Portimão. [SEP] Here the long beaches are all backed by scores of busy, large-scale tourist resorts. [SEP] The more dramatic Barlavento Coast extends west from Portimão, and is characterized by a twisting shoreline indented with coves and wind-sculpted cliffs. [SEP] The coast
column3: to an end at Cabo São Vicente, known to the medieval Portuguese as the End of the World. [SEP] The west coast of the Algarve is wilder, colder, windier, and considerably emptier, even though it has its fair share of wonderful beaches. [SEP] Inland you’ll find Roman and Moorish monuments, numerous fruit orchards, and the scenic wooded hillsides of the serras that separate the Algarve from the Alentejo. [SEP] Barlavento Coast

[SEP] This area is the best place to take advantage of the sea breezes, and many kites soar hundreds of feet up in the air. [SEP] When collisions occur or lines get crossed, jovial banter breaks out between the parties — it’s a very social activity. [SEP] The grassy area, cut by one gravel path, leads to the end of the promontory — and the mighty Fuerte San Felipe del Morro, usually simply referred to as “El Morro” (meaning “the headland”). [SEP] On your right as you walk toward the entrance you’ll pass the old city cemetery resting between the walls and the sea. [SEP] Magens Bay is a beautiful stretch of sand with a slight kink in the center, which gives it the epithet “heart-shaped.” [SEP] Because it is so sheltered, it’s a safe place for children to swim and for everyone to snorkel, though it can get very busy. Vallarta, just across the southbound bridge — is known as Rockin’ Row, for its eclectic collection of clubs. [SEP] Within easy walking distance from one another, you’ll find a blues club, a Harley-Davidson-theme rock n’ roll club, a salsa dance club, live mariachi music, a glitzy gay club (with nightly leather ranch-hands’ show), an alternative dance club, and a sports bar. [SEP] Still, the malecón rules when it
column3: to sheer rowdy nighttime fun. [SEP] Along with the longstanding Carlos O’Brians, several open-air bars and dance clubs stay open until 5am, and a new Cuban restaurant-bar pleases patrons with authentic food and live music nightly until 3am. [SEP] Just a few blocks in back of the malecón are a growing collection of unique clubs with a more urban edge. [SEP] Among them is La Cantina, a hipper version of a Mexican classic. [SEP] By day it serves classic cantina fare, by night it clamors with the sound of conversation mixed with the best in contemporary recorded Mexican music. [SEP] Board games are available for play. column1: Best Buys Ceramics. [SEP] Both Talavera ceramics from Puebla, and majolica ceramics are found in the region — but don’t mistake one for the other. [SEP] Both have the same style, using bright colors like yellow, burnt orange, and royal blue, or a blue and off-white scheme, in designs that include flowers, birds and geometric shapes. [SEP] The only way that you can tell them apart is by looking on the back of the piece and checking for the mark and the signature of the maker — only ceramics that have been handcrafted in Talavera, Puebla can be called “Talavera.” [SEP] All other ceramics with the same technique and design are known as “majolica.” [SEP] Because Talavera
column3: from a very specific region and only a few workshops produce this type of ceramic, it is more expensive than majolica, even though majolica can be just as beautiful. [SEP] Leather goods. [SEP] Jalisco is especially noted for its tooled leather goods, an art stemming from the traditions of the charros (Mexican ranchers, highly skilled in the roping and handling of horses), dating back to the days of the haciendas. [SEP] No self-respecting charro would be caught without his cinturón piteado, a tooled leather belt, decorated with piteado, a type of fine work where thin threads are sewn into the leather forming beautiful flower or geometric patterns that may even include the owner’s name.
